awd_titl_txt: Fourier analysis and partial differential equations
awd_abstract_narration:
The principal investigator on this project is Charles Fefferman, and the co-principal investigator is Elias Stein. The project involves research in harmonic analysis, theoretical fluid dynamics, materials science, and statistics. Harmonic analysis is a basic tool in science and engineering. Fluids also arise in many problems of science and technology, but our fundamental understanding of their behavior is very primitive. The materials that will be studied include graphene and its photonic analogues, which are widely regarded as having great promise for technology. The statistics problems to be studied entail fitting to a given data set a smooth object (say, a graph or a "manifold"), which has become a standard strategy for studying big data.

Fefferman hopes to understand extension and interpolation of functions in the context of Sobolev spaces; to provide efficient algorithms for selection problems geared to m-times smoothly differentiable functions; to demonstrate new mechanisms for singularity formation for fluid equations; and to obtain asymptotic formulas for the lifetimes of edge resonances in graphene-like materials. Stein seeks to produce counterexamples to demonstrate the optimality of his previous estimates in Lebesgue spaces for Cauchy-type integrals in several complex variables; to obtain dimension-free estimates by techniques he had developed earlier to study discrete analogues; and to obtain analogous results in the setting of nilpotent Lie groups.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Together with collaborators PI Fefferman continued to investigate the quantum mechanics of graphene, a material of great interest in physics and technology.  The PI completed a classification of  (rational) edges on which electrons stick without moving rapidly.

 

Together with different collaborators, the PI investigated the problem of fitting to data a smooth function subject to constraints e.g., the function must be positive or lie between zero and one.  They produced an efficient algorithm to find nearly optimal solutions to such problems.

 

Fefferman and the collaborator analyzed systems of equations for unknown semialgebraic functions. Roughly speaking a semialgebraic function is one that can be described by simple formulas.

 

The result pertains to systems of equations that can be stated using only semialgebraic functions. If such a system of equations admits a solution with a given degree of smoothness ("C^m smooth"), then the equations admit a semialgebraic solution with the same degree of smoothness. A graduate student supported by the grant analyzed the Muskat equation in a highly unstable regime.  The Muskat equation governs the evolution e.g., of oil and water and sand.  In the unstable regime in question, solutions are known to exist only if the interface between the two fluids is extraordinary smooth.  (real analytic).  The student proved that such extremely smooth interfaces are the only ones for which solutions exist.  For this research she was awarded the dissertation prize of the Association of Women in Mathematics.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/09/2022
Modified by: Charles Fefferman

Together with different collaborators, the PI investigated the problem of fitting to data a smooth function subject to constraints e.g., the function must be positive or lie between zero and one.  They produced an efficient algorithm to find nearly optimal solutions to such problems.

 

Fefferman and the collaborator analyzed systems of equations for unknown semialgebraic functions. Roughly speaking a semialgebraic function is one that can be described by simple formulas.

 

The result pertains to systems of equations that can be stated using only semialgebraic functions. If such a system of equations admits a solution with a given degree of smoothness ("C^m smooth"), then the equations admit a semialgebraic solution with the same degree of smoothness. A graduate student supported by the grant analyzed the Muskat equation in a highly unstable regime.  The Muskat equation governs the evolution e.g., of oil and water and sand.  In the unstable regime in question, solutions are known to exist only if the interface between the two fluids is extraordinary smooth.  (real analytic).  The student proved that such extremely smooth interfaces are the only ones for which solutions exist.  For this research she was awarded the dissertation prize of the Association of Women in Mathematics.
